metadata.case_name: Dunlop Rubber Co. Ltd. v. Workmen

facts.text: Dunlop Rubber Co. Ltd. processes rubber through Banbury Section, Dual Auto Mill (produces batches of 1250 lbs), and Baby Mill.
Two Dual Auto Mills operated in three 8-hour shifts with 12 workmen (2 per mill per shift), expected to produce 17 batches per shift until January 12, 1960.
Workmen grouped under unions: Union No. 4145 (Dunlop Workers Union, unregistered by company, majority), Union No. 729 (Dunlop Rubber Factory Labour Union, recognised).
Union No. 4145 raised demand for wage revision resisted by company; Dual Auto Mills and Baby Mill manned mostly by Union 4145 workmen except Raghunandan Das (Union 729).
From January 12, 1960, output of Dual Auto Mills fell from 17 to 15 batches or less in all shifts after Raghunandan Das went on leave.
On January 15, 1960, warnings issued to Dual Auto Mill workmen for going slow, stating go slow is misconduct under Standing Orders cl. 10 XVI and Labour Union Agreement cl. 18 C.
Raghunandan Das resumed duty January 19, 1960, teamed with Chandramma Chaube; quarrel on January 21, 1960, Das abused Chaube and Union 4145.
Union 4145 members threatened to stop work unless Das transferred; refused to resume work despite requests.
Dual Auto Mills closed or below capacity; workmen (12 Dual Auto + others) suspended January 25/27, 1960.
Domestic enquiry commenced February 4, 1960 by P.K. Maitra; workmen demanded representative from Union 4145, refused as only recognised union allowed; proceeded ex parte except S.R. Sen Gupta.
Enquiry officer found go slow, recommended dismissal; company dismissed 12 workmen, sought permission under s.33 IDA.
Government intercession: 10 workmen reinstated (selected by Union 4145), including all Banbury Mill; 11 Dual Auto Mill and Sen Gupta (Baby Mill) remained dismissed.
Dispute referred by West Bengal Government July 20, 1960 under s.10 Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 to Third Industrial Tribunal.

Tribunal award September 29, 1962: set aside dismissal, reinstated 12 workmen with continuity of service, 25% back wages treating period as leave; held enquiry improper, strike technically illegal but peaceful.
Special leave to appeal granted January 21, 1963.
Log books showed 'slow work' from January 12, 1960; workmen's explanation of cold mixture from Banbury Mill false as festooner operated earlier without complaint; production normalized later.

legal_issues.text: Whether the domestic enquiry was proper, particularly refusal of representation by unrecognised union.
Whether the charge-sheet adequately charged go-slow under Standing Orders cl. 10 VIII and XVI.
Whether go-slow was proved and justified dismissal despite pending industrial dispute.
Whether Tribunal justified in interfering with company's dismissal order.

petitioner_arguments.text: Enquiry proper; go-slow charged via warning letter of Jan 15 and charge-sheet under cl. 10 VIII & XVI; proved by output fall, log books; major misconduct.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Company Standing Orders cl. 10 VIII, XVI

petitioner_arguments.text: Representation only by recognised union per Standing Orders; refusal not denial of natural justice.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Kalindi v. Tata Locomotive; Brook Bond v. Subba Raman

petitioner_arguments.text: No discrimination; reinstated workmen selected by Union 4145.

respondent_arguments.text: Company did not charge go-slow explicitly; favoured Union 729; contributed to strike by not transferring Das.
Enquiry improper due to denial of Union 4145 representative; strike peaceful, technically illegal.

court_reasoning.text: Charge-sheet referred to go-slow via prior warning and Standing Orders; workmen understood and denied it; proved by output records.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Deliberate go-slow from Jan 12 to force wage demands.

court_reasoning.text: Refusal of unrecognised union representative per Standing Orders; no right to representation unless provided; not denial of natural justice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Workmen insisted on union capacity, not individual choice.

court_reasoning.text: Go-slow major misconduct; Tribunal erred in re-appreciating evidence; dismissal justified despite illegal strike.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Key operation slowed, causing loss; motive union recognition and wages.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal acted as court of appeal; no bona fides issue in company action; no discrimination by company.

holdings.text: Domestic enquiry valid; no denial of natural justice in refusing unrecognised union representative.
Go-slow adequately charged and fully substantiated as major misconduct under Standing Orders.
Dismissal justified; Tribunal not justified in interfering.
Company has free hand in internal management absent mala fides.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kalindi Ors. v. Tata Locomotive Engineering Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: No right to representation at domestic enquiry unless Standing Orders provide.

precedents_cited.case_name: Brook Bond India P. Ltd. v. Subba Raman
precedents_cited.relevance: Refusal to allow representation unless Standing Orders confer right does not vitiate proceedings.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference of dispute; permission for dismissal during pendency.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Trade Unions Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Registration of unions; representation only by registered and recognised union.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; Tribunal's award set aside; company's dismissal order upheld. Workmen lose jobs due to go-slow and illegal strike tactics for union recognition and wages.
outcome.relief_granted: None to workmen; company's order restored.

key_quotes.text: "The Tribunal was wrong in almost all its conclusions."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Summarises court's reversal of Tribunal findings.

key_quotes.text: "Refusal to allow representation by any Union unless the Standing Orders confer that right does not vitiate the proceedings."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on natural justice in enquiries.

key_quotes.text: "No outside agency should impose its will unless the action of the Company is lacking in bona fides or is manifestly perverse or unfair."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle on judicial interference in management.
